document.docTitle: Pollen morphology of some Veronica species (Plantaginaceae) from Turkey

paragraph.docTitle:
Pollen morphology of some
Veronica species
( Plantaginaceae ) from Turkey

subSection.paragraph: KADER VARLIK 1,4 * , METİN ARMAĞAN 2,5 & ALİ SAVAŞ BÜLBÜL 3,6

paragraph.docAuthorAffiliation: Kahramanmaraş Sütçü İmam University, Faculty of Science and Arts, Department of Biology , Kahramanmaraş , Turkey
Necmettin Erbakan University, Ereğli Faculty of Agriculture, Field Crop Department, Konya , Turkey
Bayburt University, Faculty of Applied Sciences , Department of Emergency Aid and Disaster Management, Bayburt , Turkey

subSection.paragraph:
4
�
kadervarlik@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-9887-5942

5
�
metinarmagan@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-3913-954X

6
�
asavasbulbu@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-2200-7348
*Author for correspondence

The aim of the present work is to provide an account on the morphological features of pollen of
Veronica species
in Turkey , as a contribution to future research. Pollen morphology of 20 species of the
Veronica
were investigated using Light Microscope (LM) and Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). Different palyno-morphological features including; pollen ornamentation, colpus ornamentation, size of polar and equatorial diameter, P/E ratio, exine thickness, and size of colpus were observed. The study revealed that the pollen grains of the studied
Veronica species
were in all cases tricolpate, radially symmetrical and isopolar, oblate-spheroidal or prolate spheroidal. The surface pattern of the exine varied from striato-reticulate and striatomicroreticulate to microechinate-perforate, which allows recognition of three homonymous types of pollen grains.

Keywords: Light Microscopy, Plantaginaceae, Pollen morphology, Scanning Electron Microscopy, Turkey ,
Veronica

The genus
Veronica Linnaeus (1753: 9)
was previously classified in the
Scrophulariaceae Jussieu (1789: 117)
family. Now, it has been included in the
Plantaginaceae Jussieu (1789: 89)
following many taxonomic studies conducted on the genus worldwide (APG 1998, 2003, 2009, 2016,
Albach et al. 2004
). The Plantaginaceae is a large family that includes 101 genera and 1700−1900 species (APG 1998, 2003, 2009,
Albach et al. 2004
).

Veronica
is one of the largest genera of Plantaginaceae . It comprises of about 450 species distributed nearly all over the Northern Hemisphere and many parts of the Southern Hemisphere in the world.
Veronica
taxa are ecologically diverse, with species that can grow in aquatic and dry steppe habitats, from sea level to high alpine elevations (
Christenhusz et al. 2016
). The genus
Veronica
has approximately 107 taxa in Turkey , 35 of which are endemic ( Fischer 1984 , Ekim 2000 , Öztürk 2001 ,
Albach et al. 2008
).

Many authors have studied the palynology of the
Veronica species.
Risch (1939) reported the first palynological records on the genus. In the years that followed, Varghese (1968) , Huang (1972) , Hong & Nilsson (1983) , and Hong (1984) studied
Veronica
and related genera.
Fernández et al. (1997)
examined the pollen morphology and taxonomic features of
Veronica species
in Spain , whereas
Martínez-Ortega et al . (2000)
studied some species of that genus from the Western Mediterranean area. Mehrvarz & Zarrei (2006) examined the pollen morphology of some
Veronica species
in Iran .
Sánchez Agudo et al. (2009)
described the pollen morphology of 134 populations of the genus
Veronica
from the Mediterranean Region in detail. However, the pollen morphology of
Veronica
remains poorly documented in Turkey ,
Başer et al. (2020)
being the only authors who examined palynologic characteristics of some Turkish
Veronica species.

In the present study, the pollen morphology of the twenty species of
Veronica
known to occur in Turkey was investigated. Among them, seven were reported for the first time, and five endemics to Turkey were also studied.
Veronica
is arranged into 13 subgenera by
Albach et al. (2004
, 2008 ), seven of which include the studied Turkish species as follows: 1. subgen.
Pellidosperma
(
V. donii Römpp
); 2. subgen.
Pentasepalae
(
V. caespitosa Boiss.
,
V. bombycina Boiss. & Kotschy subsp. froediniana Rech.
f.,
V. orientalis Mill. subsp. nimrodi (Richt. ex Stapf) M.A.Fisch.
,
V. orientalis Mill. subsp. orientalis
,
V. multifida
L.,
V. macrostachya Vahl subsp. mardinensis (Bornm.) M.A.Fisch.
,
V. microcarpa Boiss.
); 3. subgen.
Triangulicapsula
(
V. grisebachii Walters
); 4. subgen.
Chamaedrys
(
V. chamaedrys
L.); 5. subgen.
Pocilla
(
V. polita Fr.
,
V. persica Poir.
); 6. subgen.
Cochlidiosperma
(
V. cymbalaria Bodard
); and 7. subgen.
Beccabunga
(
V. gentianoides Vahl subsp. glacialis (Nábelek) A.Öztürk & M.A.Fisch.
,
V. beccabunga
L.,
V. anagalloides Guss. subsp. heureka M.A.Fisch.
,
V. anagallis-aquatica
L. subsp.
anagallis-aquatica
,
V. anagallisaquatica
L.
subsp. lysimachioides (Boiss.) M.A.Fisch.
,
V. bozakmanii M.A.Fisch.
,
V. debilis Freyn
).

Although the morphology of pollen grains of
Veronica
is well studied palynologically, only very few similar studies have been conducted on Turkish species to date. Therefore, the present study aims to fill this gap in knowledge by analysing palynologically the endemic and non-endemic species of
Veronica
and ultimately by providing information that will contribute to a better classification of the genus.

For the present study, samples of 20 Turkish taxa of
Veronica
were collected at various times from different parts of Turkey by one of the authors (M. Armağan), without focusing specially in any region or group. The collected samples were dried and prepared based on herbarium methods, and conserved in the herbarium KNYA (acronym according to Thiers 2021). Various editions of Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean Islands ( Fischer 1978 , Davis 1988 , Ekim 2000 ) were used as the initial reference for identification. Plant names and authors were checked from different sources ( Bizimbitkiler 2013 , POWO 2019 , IPNI 2020 , WFO 2020 ). A list of taxa and full voucher information are provided in Table 1 .

Pollen grains were examined with light microscope (LM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM). Pollen slides were prepared using the Wodehouse (1935) technique. The pollen grains were stained with glycerin-jelly containing basic fuchsin and the slide was gently heated. The prepared slides were covered with a lamella and then were studied under a light microscope and photographed with a Leica DM 750 digital imaging system. Measurements were based on at least 30 pollen grains per specimen. Polar and equatorial diameter, colpus length, colpus width, apocolpium, mesocolpium and exine thickness were measured to obtain the mean values. Both qualitative and quantitative characteristics of pollen grains were noted by using LM. The analysis of data was performed using SPSS (2016) package to determine the maximum, minimum, mean (in parenthesis) and standard deviation of each quantitative feature. Micrographs, which showed general wiew of pollen surface, were taken with a JEOL Tescan model electron microscope in Bartın University Central Research Laboratory. For SEM, specimens were mounted directly onto stubs, using single-sided adhesive tape, and coated with gold.

The descriptive terminology follows
Halbritter et al. (2018)
. Furthermore, the size and shape classification and the P/E ratios according to Erdtman (1945 , 1952 ) are shown in Table 3 .

The pollen morphological characters of the 20 studied species of the genus
Veronica
are summarised in Tables 1−4 . SEM and LM images are shown in Figs. 1−8 .

Shape, symmetry and size: The pollen grains of
Veronica
are isopolar and radially symmetric. Erdtman (1945) categorised the different pollen size classes based on length of the longest axis. According to his classification, the examined species are medium-size. The dominant pollen morphology was oblate-spheroidal (16 species), while
V. bozakmanii
,
V. debilis
,
V. gentianoides subsp. glacialis
, and
V. polita
showed prolate-spheroidal grains.The maximum polar diameter was observed in
V. donii
[31.18−45.48 (36.2) µm], whereas it was minimum in
V. bozakmanii
[17.25−39.4 (26.22) µm]. The equatorial diameter rank was again maximum in
V. donii
[32.67−47 (40.14) µm] and minimum in
V. bozakmanii
[14.85−35.9 (23.64) µm]. P/E ratio for each species ( Fig. 1 and Table 3 ) was determined by the ratio of polar to equatorial diameter, and it ranged from 0.9 (
V. donii
) to 1.12 (
V. bozakmanii
). Quantitative results obtained after comparison of polar and equatorial diameter of pollen in different species are shown in Fig. 2 .

Apertures: Pollen grains are tricolpate. Aperture length is more than 2 times the aperture width. The apertures are elongated; they reach the poles of the grain with rounded or acute ends. Apertural membrane covered with various exine elements which are granulate, verrucate or rugulate-perforate, irregularly arranged. As for the mean values of colpus length (clg) and width (clt), they were highest in
V. donii
(clg= 28.04 µm, clt= 16.12 µm), whereas lowest in
V. anagalloides subsp. heureka
(clg = 18.28 µm, clt =8.80 µm). The apocolpium diameter ranged from a maximum in
V. donii
(6.78 µm) to a minimum in
V. anagallis-aquatica
subsp.
anagallis-aquatica
[14.85−35.9 (23.64) µm].

Veronica
taxa examined in this study.

subSection.paragraph:
Thickness of exine: The maximum exine thickness value was found in
V.anagallis-aquatica subsp. lysimachioides
[1.44−3.21 (2.04) µm] and the minimum occurred in
V. microcarpa
[1.0-1.5 (1.17) µm].

subSection.paragraph:
Pollen types :
On the basis of exine surface characteristics, the pollen of the studied species of
Veronica
can be included into three groups:

Type 1. Striato-reticulate
: This pattern is constituted by elongated parallel rows of muri linked to form a reticulum within the grooves; the connections between muri likely lie on single level or dissimilar levels. This type is found in
V. beccabunga
,
V. bombycina subsp. froediniana
,
V. bozakmanii
,
V. chamaedrys
,
V. gentianoides subsp. glacialis
,
V. multifida
,
V. orientalis subsp. nimrodi
, and
V. orientalis subsp. orientalis
.

Type 2. Striato-microreticulate
: Based on size ornamentation elements which are (0.5–1 μm), this pattern can be defined as microreticulate (
Halbritter et al. 2018
). It is dominant among the studied species and occurs in
V. anagallisaquatica
subsp.
anagallis-aquatica
,
V. anagallis-aquatica subsp. lysimachioides
,
V. anagalloides subsp. heureka
,
V. caespitosa
,
V. debilis
,
V. grisebachii
,
V. persica
,
V. macrostachya subsp. mardinensis
,
V. microcarpa
, and
V. polita
.

Type 3. Microechinate-perforate
: Microechinate pattern is formed by pointed sculpturing elements (echini) less than 1μm in height; perforate applies to surfaces having small holes or pits. It is found in
V. cymbalaria
and
V. donii
.

The present study shows that the shape of pollen grains in the Turkish species of
Veronica
is prolate-spheroidal or oblate-spheroidal. This indicates that no prominent differences were found in pollen shapes of the studied taxa. The main features of pollen are illustrated in Fig. 1–8 , and summarised in Tables 2–3 .

The study also shows that the pollen grains can be arranged into three groups, based on the type of exine ornamentation: Type 1 or Striato-reticulate type includes 8 species; Type 2 or Striato-microreticulate type comprises 10 species, and Type 3 or Microechinate-perforate type with oly 2 species.

Different definitions on pollen ornamentation of
Veronica
have been used in previous studies (
Fernández et al. 1997
, Saeidi-Mehrvarz & Zarrei 2006 ). The existence of conflicting terminology to describe similar exine morphology has caused confusion. Consequently, Sánchez-Agudo et al. (2009) suggested a standard nomenclature for the exine ornamentation definition in
Veronica
by following the terminology of
Punt et al. (2007)
. The comparison of the exine ornamentation of taxa analysed in those previous studies is presented in Table 4 .
Punt et al. (2007)
provided informative schematic drawings containing the fundamentals of each term mostly using LM observations. However,
Halbritter et al. (2018)
presented a comprehensive overview of all aspects of pollen characteristics, such as both structure and sculpture that includes various LM and SEM images. Therefore, in the present study
Halbritter et al. (2018)
is preferred for pollen terminology.

Fernández et al. (1997)
reported that the exine ornamentation of
V. cymbalaria
was scabrate.
Sánchez Agudo et al. (2009)
found that the exine ornamentation of
V. cymbalaria
and
V. donii
were scabrate-perforate.
Halbritter et al. (2018)
suggested that the scabrate term should be used only for LM, describing minute sculpture elements of undefined shape and size. Hence, in our opinion it is more accurate to use the term microechinate-perforate to describe the exine ornamentation of
V. cymbalaria
and
V. donii
.

Veronica anagallis-aquatica
subsp.
anagallis-aquatica
,
V. persica
and
V. polita
were defined as rugulate by
Fernández et al. (1997)
, while Saeidi-Mehrvarz & Zarrei (2006) referred it as rugulate-perforate. Sánchez-Agudo et al. (2009) reported onwards that exine ornamentation of these species was striato-reticulate. In our study, due to the presence of small ornamental elements (0.5-1 μm in size), these three species are defined as striato-microreticulate.

The average polar and equatorial lengths of pollen (pl×pe) for
V. anagalis-aquatica
were found to vary depending on the different authors. Those measurements reached 23×16 µm ( Saeidi-Mehrvarz & Zarrei 2006 ), 27.65×22.02 µm (
Başer et al. 2020
), 28.82×27.67 µm (
Fernández et al. 1997
), or 30×24.72 µm (
Sánchez Agudo et al. 2009
). In the present study, the average polar length of
V. anagalis-aquatica
subsp.
anagallis-aquatica
was 30.46 µm, and its average equatorial length was 31.39 µm. It is important to note that the preparation of pollen grains for LM observations were different in some cases, namely
Fernández et al. (1997)
, Saeidi-Mehrvarz & Zarrei (2006) and
Sánchez Agudo et al. (2009)
used Erdtman’s (1960) method, while
Başer et al. (2020)
used Wodehouse’s (1935) as we did. Regarding the pollen grain shape,
V. cymbalaria
is found to be oblate-spheroidal in our study, whereas Sánchez-Agudo et al. (2009) described it as prolate-spheroidal. The reasons for the differences observed among the results obtained here and previous authors are perhaps due to different eco-physiological conditions in various regions rather than the method used for observations.

After the palynological analysis of the
Veronica
taxa examined in the present study, it can be concluded that (1) the most important qualitative feature of pollen grains corresponds to pollen exine ornamentation, and (2) the diagnostic value of the studied quantitative pollen grain features is not remarkable. Therefore, for a correct and accurate species identification the pollen characteristics alone are not relevant enough, and they are to be combined with other morphological features.
